results.title: Continental drift: the theory of plate tectonics
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Outlines the major features of the theory of plate tectonics and notes how the theory can be used to explain the distribution of the world’s major earthquake zones and areas of volcanic activity. Provides ample evidence to support the validity of the theory of plate tectonics and explores some possible explanations as to how the plates actually move. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Continental drift
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Joseph Koenig and Co Hoedeman
results.brief_description: An exposition through film animation of the theory that Earth’s land areas are fluid and that, in the process of a slow, rolling, boiling motion, one part of the Earth might well be engulfed and then rise again some distance away, much the same as froth on a kettle of soup. From this theory comes the idea that continents were formed from one super-continent that broke up, whose pieces sank, and then rose once more, but far apart. Introducing the film is Professor J. Tuzo Wilson, geophysicist, University of Toronto. Animation by Co Hoedeman. (Award: London.)

results.title: Continental Circus
results.brief_description:
The racing careers and exploits of two contrasting characters are explored in this French documentary about small motorcycle racing. One is the Australian Jack Findlay, who manages to stay in the game through sheer spunk and the help of his French wife and many friends. He often has accidents, lacks a corporate sponsor, and sometimes must borrow even the machines he races with. Giacomo Agostini, on the other hand, seems to be singularly blessed. As the reigning champion (in 1971) and a noteworthy playboy, he has all the sponsorship he could ask for, and wins his races without injuries or spills. This film highlights the difficulty and even fatal dangers of this form of racing. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1972.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Zajderman ; director, Jerome Laperrousaz ; writer, Jerome Laperrousaz ; photography, Jimmy Glasberg, Jean-Paul Jansen, Raymond Meyer ; music, Gong.
Cast: Jack Findlay, Nanou, Giacomo Agostini.

results.title: Continent in crisis
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Malcolm Paterson and David Smith
results.brief_description: The Australian environment is in severe ecological crisis with soil degradation, salinity and deforestation all taking their toll on the land. But it is not all doom and gloom. Through satellite technology using remote sensing and computer analysis, scientists are able to plot the landscape on a daily, even hourly, basis and chart such occurrences as bushfires, floods, vegetation regrowth etc. This allows for future planning both environmentally and economically. “Continent in crisis” is a celebration of Australia’s natural beauty from the red centre, to the rainforests to the Great Barrier Reef and of the world-ranking environmental research being undertaken by CSIRO and others.

results.title: Contemporary trends
results.creator_credit: Center for Humanities and Eve Cotton
results.brief_description: This video describes the American art scene in the 1940’s when painters in New York developed Abstract Expressionism. Among the artists represented are Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline, Adolph Gottlieb and Mark Rothko. Also examines the Minimal, Pop, Conceptual and Photorealist movements.

results.title: Contemporary Scandinavia: common purposes, individual differences
results.creator_credit: Richard Kaplan Productions, McGraw-Hill Films and Richard Kaplan
results.brief_description: An overview of modern life in Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Describes their unique political organisation, stressing at the same time, national differences. Discusses the influence of both geography and modern technology on economic and social organisation, and Scandinavia’s role in world affairs. Includes a sequence on youth and education.

results.title: Contemporary case studies
results.creator_credit: Go Girl Productions and Janet Merewether
results.brief_description: A wry comment on the state of heterosexual romance and sex in the 21st century from a female perspective, this short experimental film consists of nine case studies ‘as witnessed from life’. Through the use of split-screens Merewether juxtaposes text and images to comment on the all-too-familiar scenarios, conversations and discussions that constitute modern day (mis)understandings about what women do and don’t want. Photography by Jackie Farkas.

results.title: Container port
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films, IC Productions, Edgar H. Anstey, James Ritchie and Ian Woolfe
results.brief_description: The story of the development of Tilbury into Britain’s biggest and newest container port, built and equipped to tranship standard maritime containers which are the key to a world-wide revolution in freight handling. Commentary by John Stockbridge.

results.title: Contact [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Robert Zemeckis and Steve Starkey
results.brief_description: The search for life outside our solar system becomes a personal and spiritual quest for Ellie Arroway, a scientist who has lost her faith in God after her parents died when she was a child. However, she has learned to develop a different sort of faith in the seemingly unknowable, working with a group that monitors radio waves from space in a hope that some day she will receive a message from another world- proving there is a world beyond our own. When the team picks up a signal that does not appear to be of earthly origin, Ellie decodes the message and discovers what appear to be plans for a space craft, which she takes as an invitation. Ellie and her researchers soon run into interference however from a White House scientific adviser who cuts their funding and tries to take credit for their achievements. Cast includes Jodie Foster, Matthew McConaughey, James Woods, John Hurt and Tom Skerritt.
